segments.text: We loaded every possession that we had in our car in the smallest little U-Haul trailer that you can rent and drove to Auburn, Alabama.
And we did have an apartment ready, so we knew where we were going to rent.
So that was a true experience.
At that point, was Pierre Matty, was he kind of a role model for you as a scholar-scientist?
Absolutely.
He was clearly a role model, both as a professional.
He had the professional demeanor, the professional dress.
But he was also a premier surgeon.
And, yeah, he was the role model, no question.
And what did Dean Price say when you chatted with him?

It was very encouraging, and I had gotten to know Dean Price quite well because I was president of my class in the veterinary college, so periodically I met with him for various issues, and then I was president of the

student body and the American Veterinary Medical Association student chapter actually got to go to Portland, Oregon on the same plane with him to the national meeting of the American Veterinary Medical Association.
So I had gotten to know him and had been in such leadership roles in the veterinary college that he was more than just the dean of the college.
By then we had
a personal relationship, and he was very encouraging.
All right, let's stay with him just a second.
Both then and later, describe as much as you can about Al Price.
Al Price was a visionary leader who was able to make tough decisions
and who was, I believe, a tremendous communicator with the faculty and the students.
And he was a person, you knew where he stood.
You knew what his standards were.
And he implemented some pretty tough changes in going from the four year to the three year year round.
And he was a role model.
And there was no question.
And there was no question who was the dean of the college.
And there was no question but what the highest standards of character and integrity would be upheld.
And if you didn't uphold those as a student, you wouldn't be there.
And we held the students and we held ourselves to such an incredibly high standard.
If any student was caught cheating in the College of Veterinary Medicine,
It was goodbye, and there was no second chance, and people knew that.
And as far as you all knew, Price was around a lot.
You saw him.
You saw him a great deal, absolutely.
Never heard anything negative about him?
No, not always.
He was a gentleman, treated students and faculty with a great respect.
And as far as I was aware,

although veterinary medicine numerically, its student body wasn't large compared to the rest of it, that his image with the central administration of the campus was such that veterinary medicine was certainly treated equally fairly in every manner.
And I think that was generally felt by the faculty that we interacted with, and I think it was generally felt by the veterinary students because there was such
a pride of being selected to be in the class.
And you didn't want to let anyone down.
And there was a standard there, which I think is really the Aggie code of honor, that you didn't want to be the one that might not have upheld it.
When did a veterinary student buy a senior ring?

Well, back then, since there was no undergraduate degree program per se, after the second trimester of your second year in veterinary college, which would be December, you would be given a baccalaureate degree.
It was a BS in veterinary science.
So once you're going through that

process of the two years and then your first year in when you got the adequate number of hours you could go get your senior ring and that was one of the greatest days of my life and I remember distinctly then you picked them up in Eaton Hall and I can remember as if it were yesterday of walking up to the second floor walking up those stairs and it was on the left when you got to the top of the stairs walking in there and picking up that ring and putting it on.
Do you remember what it cost?
It was something like $28 or $58.
It was small back then.
Do you have any Aggie Ring stories, anecdotes?
Have you ever lost it?
I've never lost it.
The only time that I really remember was after I was at Auburn.
My wife and I were going to be sponsors for a group of veterinary students to go to Panama City, Florida.
And we were leaving, and she looked at me, and she said, where's your Aggie Ring?
And I said, oh.
But I also looked at the other hand, and my wedding band wasn't there either.
And what had happened was I had done surgery that day, and when I scrubbed, I'd left them in my clinic jacket.
So we drove all the way back to the small animal clinic, and I got my Aggie ring and my wedding band at the same time.
Have you ever been at some unusual place and somebody wrecked it?
Oh, yeah.
Where?
We went later.
My wife and I and our two daughters, when they were both...
up in high school to Los Angeles and they wanted to go to Hollywood and the movie studios and some things there.
And I was at the airport at a car rental agency checking the car in and I look over next to me and here's this guy filling out his papers with an Aggie ring.
I immediately whip out to him and he was from Minnesota, now living in Minnesota.
So we whipped out to each other.
So it's the calling card
around the world.
Describe commencement, vet school commencement.

Vet school commencement was held in Bryan Civic Auditorium and of course that was a small group and that seats about 1,500 so it was adequate size for us and all of our family and Charlie Scruggs I remember is the who gave the commencement.
You know most of the time you don't remember who spoke at commencement but I do remember him.
And of course, it was such a special time because not only had no one in either side of my family ever gone to college, but here was the first one now getting a doctor's degree.
So special because not only did you receive the doctoral role, but they hooded you on stage and then pronounced you doctor of veterinary medicine.
And I could just look at my mom and dad and just see them beaming with such pride because my dad had been offered a scholarship, academic, to A&M, but World War II caught him.
And when he got back, then he had a wife and me, and he could never financially go.
So it meant so much to him.
And it was an emotional time, it really was.
And Kathy, my wife's family was there.
It was a celebration.
About how many of those 64 graduated?
I believe that we ended with 62 out of the 64.
Wow.
That's better than usual, isn't it?
Oh, yeah.
Let's see.
Korean veterans were already gone.
They were gone.
Although there were probably a few in our class that were older and had come back.
And Vietnam was not yet.
It was just beginning.
It hadn't produced any.
No.
I'll tell you something interesting.
We're talking about that time frame.
It's like when I started dating Kathy.
for her to come over from the University of Texas or when she came up from Corpus, the greatest challenge was to find a place for her to stay.
Of course, we couldn't afford her to stay in a motel or hotel.
Plus, there were only about three or four in the whole town.
So you know what we did?
We found a friend that we knew, somebody at church.
Or what was good was a number of classmates that were married.
And a lot of times we'd say, hey, you live out, you've got a house, could she stay over there?
And then when we lived out at Welburn, there was a girl out there named Alexander, and a lady probably in her late 70s lived alone, and she let her stay out there.
That's a great challenge, I think.
Yes, it is.
If you're going to speak out of town, what would you do?
The center pole of this campus.
And I believe today.
In fact, I will tell you later.
But that was one.
I'm going to tell you one that's funny.
I'm on the great side.
Oh, yes.
Growing up, that was the campus site.
And then college, most of the time, we would try to take them to see that part, because that was impressive back in its day.
the facilities today, it's just an incredible medical facility.
All right, now you got to Auburn in August of 66?
That's September of 66, that's correct.
And you were there how long?
I was there almost three years.
All right, describe that.
What did you do there?
That was an interesting experience for me because I graduated on August the 5th,
and started work there August the 15th.
And they were short a small animal surgeon.
And here I am supposedly doing research and doing my graduate work thrown into the full responsibilities of a faculty member teaching surgery to fourth year veterinary students.
And many of them had had four years of undergrad and now they were in their fourth year.
So they had eight years of college
And here I'd only had a total of five.
Most of them were older than me.
And I had not done some of the procedures.
So I'd go bone up at night or at noon hour.
And man, I was bummed.
I'd just go right in there and do the surgery.
And I was teaching surgery to a lot of them much older than me.
And then taking graduate classes.
The post-doctoral work.
was a combined residency and post-doctoral master's program with a thesis in research in surgery and neurophysiology.
So through the day, I would be working full time in the veterinary teaching hospital and taking graduate courses.
And I'm not sure I would recommend it.
That was tough.
The hours were long.
And plus, I had emergency duty.
So those were full days.
Compare Auburn to College Station and compare Auburn University to Texas A&M at that time.
Auburn was probably at that time a comparable sized university because that was really before the big growth spurt.
My last year in veterinary college was when A&M started its growth because it admitted women.
Auburn was probably 12,000.
and a good university, but it was clearly not Texas.
It struggled with funding, but later down my academic career, it was good for me to see the tightening of belts from an administrative standpoint.
The academic programs there in the veterinary college were very strong.
I don't believe probably the whole university had the academic statue of an A&M, but particularly in the area or the discipline that I was in, it was the number one in the country.
And they had some extremely talented, brilliant people in those areas.
And I followed an Aggie.

in the position that I took, who then went to the University of Minnesota College of Veterinary Medicine and has been head of the small animal department at the University of Georgia now for 20, 30 years.
As you made your way into the inner circle there, how did they treat Aggies?
What was their impression of what they did?
They loved Aggies because they knew Aggies were well trained and they knew Aggies were hard workers.
And fortunately, I'd had a number of Aggies go through there before I was there.
And quite frankly, I really believe they would give preference to an Aggie coming because they knew the kind of background we had and they knew our work ethic.
And they always joked with us about being from Texas.
I never got into hearing the Aggie joke.
of everything so big in Texas.

And I'll never forget when I told them that I was leaving, that I had accepted a faculty position back at A&M, one of the premier small anal orthopedic surgeons told me, he said, you know, I've always heard that an Aggie always goes back home to die.
Now your wife, did she do any teaching over there?
She taught public school.
Okay.
Was it, were newcomers well accepted in the community?
We were very well accepted.
And, you know, there was a lot of the southern hospitality, people there.
We got very active in our church and immediately formed friends.
We started working with college kids in our church.
And we had a circle of about five couples, most of whom were either our age or a little older, and they just took us in and supported us fully.
And then we were so fortunate in that the department head and his wife almost took a mentorship responsibility of us young faculty members, research associates.
And I recall so many times they'd have us in the...
Compared Auburn Southern Baptist to Texas Southern Baptist?
Virtually no difference.
Virtually no difference.
And you, all three years, you're a, over there, you're working on the Ph.D.?
I was for about the first two and a half, and then I stayed on.
They were on a quarter system.
I stayed on for another quarter as assistant professor before I took a position here in March of 1969.
What significant skills or attitudes or qualities do you think you acquired as a result of the Auburn experience?
Well, there was no question but what I learned.
research.
I learned how to conduct research.

I had the opportunity to develop surgical skills simply because of the practice of those that I got to apply there that really requires that kind of repetition to do on day in and day out and with the differences in the cases that you've dealt with.
I'll never forget that we always said, okay, who's going to hold the record for doing the most spinal neuro procedures in one week?
And when I left, I held the record.
I did 17 one week.
So that builds up because we had referral cases from all over the southeast.
because at that time there were not veterinary colleges in the other southeastern states.
And many times they drove in there from, we had cases from Canada even come in there.
And so I gained that kind of experience just of the surgical skills technique as well as the graduate courses were rigorous.
And I learned so much more of the in-depth neurophysiology surgery
just the academic arena.
I also had the privilege of giving some lectures and classes, so that gave me some teaching experience.

And I learned a lot of people skills because when you deal with a clientele and you deal with the public and you have an emotional pet in front of you, between you, you're gonna quickly develop some people skills and communication skills.
Fortunately, I had one of the very best administrators I have ever seen in my life as a role model before me.
And I watched him because I had such an interest in leadership, which I had had since the sixth or seventh grade.
So I was already beginning to think toward the future of leadership, of administration, and education.
So I watched him, and I learned from him.
And he was like
Another administrator that I worked closely with, he was another one of those clean desk people, which I am too.
When I walk out of my office in an afternoon, there won't be a single piece of paper on that desk.
And there wasn't when I was provost or president of this university.
I handled them.
Now the Auburn Vet School in its size complexity was similar to the one here?
Yes, almost identical in size.
And it had students from a number of the southeastern states?
It had students from seven different states.
Under contract?
Under contract.
And I think they were taking, by that time, about 80 students.
We had students from Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Kentucky,
and Tennessee as a diverse group.
In terms of student quality?
Extremely high.
It was comparable to here.
Because a lot of those, since they took from seven states, those seven states could only send a contractual number.
Boy, those kids were really selected out.
They were cream of the crop.

I know nothing about this and we don't need to spend much time on it, but I used to wonder about what the political realities might have been in the selection of that very minute number from various states, what strings may have been pulled or someone tried to pull to ensure that
And they often tried to pull strings.
They even get governor's offices in those states.
That's what I would guess.
The university was a lot like A&M.
The student had to stand up on their own merit.
And so how did you find out about the possibility of a return slot here?
Well, that's interesting because even when I had left A&M, I had talked to the people in medicine and surgery.
They knew what I was going to be doing.
going on for post-doctoral work.
So they were .
I knew that they did not have anyone here in the specialty of neurosurgery, and they desperately needed it.
So about the time that I had finished all my post-doctoral work, I get a call from the head of medicine and surgery here.
indicating that they were going to have a position as an assistant professor opening up.
And would I be interested?
Well, with families and this being my alma mater, being an Aggie, they didn't even need to ask me.
I was very quick to say, I want to come back.
And they said, we want you to come back.
We will let you take this whole area of neurosurgery and develop it as a new specialty within the hospital, within the curriculum.
So what more could a young person at my age want than to be able to come back here and develop that specialty?
So we made the decision in December of
So no search committee, no national ads.
Not that I'm aware of.
I think the department head and the dean's office.
Who was the department head then?
Mr. Callahan, Dr. Callahan.
Nick.
Nick Callahan.
And I'll never forget this.
We came by to finalize things with them.
And we started looking for a house.
And we looked over on Mary Oaks and found a home that we loved, but it would stretch us financially, and we knew it.
But it was not yet completed.
The inside was not.
But we went ahead and signed a contract.
And my wife selected everything in that home in one day.
And we left.
We never saw that home again until we drove up with a U-Haul truck and unloaded in March of 69.
Oh, my.
And it was beautiful.
Oh, how good, how good.
Not going to ask dollars anymore after this.
What was the beginning salary?
I believe it was somewhere around $24,000.
And did anybody give you any guidelines at all other than what you just mentioned about what your responsibilities were?
You were to develop a new area.
I was to develop a new area.
I was given a job description of what a faculty member's responsibilities would be in the small animal medicine and surgery department.

I knew what having already almost three years in the academic arena I knew what the tenure requirements would be I purposely put in that I wanted to do some additional kinds of research and I knew I would be teaching that specialty both in the clinic with a group of students as well as in the lecture room
And that I would have some student responsibilities of counseling students as they would come to me.
And so you began then in the fall of?
The spring, March of 1969.
They were still on three year?
Yes.
Still on?
Yes.
Did you turn to anyone for any particular advice early in the?
I don't recall any specific person that I went to for counsel or advice.
I knew a fair number of them because I had had some of them when I was a student as a faculty member.
I knew the department head, I knew Dr. Callahan, I knew Dr. Ellett who was head of the small animal component of it at that time.
And I know that I periodically would go to them for certain things.
But remarkably back then, you were pretty well given your job description and you were turned loose.
And I looked at it as a great advantage.
I mean, here it is, go with it.
Were there any perhaps amusing incidents of where someone spoke to you as if you were still a student, forgot that you were now their colleague?
No, I never had that.
That never happened?
I really didn't and that was very assuring so many times because I was really looked at as a colleague

Sometimes I would go to like Dr. Jean Gowing in medicine if I had a complicated case that the surgical component was now complicated because of a medical issue and I would frequently go to them for medical consultation because I knew that they were older and sage and wisdom of knowing those things so they were always there for me but
They treated me as a real peer and as a real colleague.
Now, the department at that time, about how many colleagues?
Oh, that was a big department.
I think we probably had at least about 40 people then.
And as far as you were aware, where did Texas A&M Veterinary Medicine in general and in that specialty look?
Where did Texas A&M and small animal medicine, where did it win?
It would have been in the top five.
There's no question when you go to national meetings that you would be part of it.
Texas A&M, you were one of the top five.
Who were the other top?
Cornell, University of California, Davis, University of Pennsylvania,
Maybe Ohio State at times.
They had a few weaknesses in it, but they were considered one of the better ones too.
And the facilities you were provided and the staff you were given, were they adequate?
Yes, we had good facilities.
We had good staff.
We had good staff support.
And of course, we were growing rapidly.
The Veterinary Teaching Hospital, because of the specialist
because ophthalmology was off the ground, orthopedics, dermatology, all of the specialties were just booming.
And we were almost marginal in the surgery area because of the caseload and the referral cases that were beginning to come here.
But, you know, we were pleased.
They were excellent.
The surgery...
cases in general, what were they?
Where did they come from?
They came from all over the state of Texas.
I had cases flown in here from West Texas.
I had one flown in, I'll never forget this, from some people that actually were from I think Abilene or somewhere in that area that are the owners of
the big apple orchard out in the state of Washington.
I mean, they ship all over the world.
It's a famous name, and I'm sorry I can't think of it right now.
But we met them at the airport, and they had a poodle that was paralyzed from a herniated disc, and that was my specialty.
And we met them at the airport, brought them over to the clinic, told them what we could do, and told them I thought that I could...
